Assess the effect of new levels of resources

Source: R/reconstruct.R
new_R_ps.Rd

This function calculates the effect of changing the resources available to an energy conversion chain. New versions of U, V, and Y matrices are returned as U_prime, V_prime, and Y_prime. This function assumes that each industry's inputs are perfectly substitutable (ps).

new_R_ps(
  .sutmats = NULL,
  R_prime = "R_prime",
  U = "U",
  V = "V",
  Y = "Y",
  S_units = "S_units",
  q = "q",
  C = "C",
  eta_i = "eta_i",
  maxiter = 100,
  tol = 0,
  U_prime = "U_prime",
  V_prime = "V_prime",
  Y_prime = "Y_prime"
)

Arguments

.sutmats

a data frame of supply-use table matrices with matrices arranged in columns.
R_prime

a new resource matrix or name of a column in .sutmats containing same. Default is "R_prime".
U

use (U) matrix or name of the column in .sutmats that contains same. Default is "U".
V

make (V) matrix or name of the column in .sutmatsthat contains same. Default is "V".
Y

final demand (Y) matrix or name of the column in .sutmats that contains same. Default is "Y".
S_units

S_units matrix or name of the column in .sutmats that contains same. Default is "S_units".
q

q vector or name of the column in .sutmats that contains same. Default is "q".
C

a C matrix or name of a column in .sutmats containing same. Default is "C".
eta_i

an eta_i vector or name of a column in .sutmats containing same. Default is "eta_i".
maxiter

the maximum allowable number of iterations when calculating the effects of a new R matrix. Default is 100.
tol

the maximum allowable change in any one entry of the U, V, and Y matrices from one iteration to the next. Default is 0, i.e., when two subsequent iterations produce the same values, the algorithm has converged.
U_prime

name for the U_prime matrix on output. Default is "U_prime".
V_prime

name for the V_prime matrix on output. Default is "V_prime".
Y_prime

name for the Y_prime matrix on output. Default is "Y_prime".

Value

a list or data frame containing U_prime, V_prime, and Y_prime matrices

Details

Inputs U, V, Y, S_units, q, and C can be conveniently calculated by the function calc_io_mats; eta_i can be calculated with calc_eta_i.

Each industry must be unit-homogeneous on its inputs. If not, NA is returned as the result for U_prime, V_prime, and Y_prime.

Examples

library(dplyr)
library(matsbyname)
library(tidyr)
doubleR <- UKEnergy2000mats %>%
  spread(key = "matrix.name", value = "matrix") %>%
  # Calculate the input-output matrices which are inputs to the new_R function.
  calc_io_mats() %>%
  # Calculate the efficiency of every industry in the ECC.
  calc_eta_i() %>%
  # Make an R_prime matrix that gives twice the resource inputs to the economy.
  mutate(
    R_prime = hadamardproduct_byname(2, R)
  ) %>%
  # Now call the new_R function which will calculate
  # updated U, V, and Y matrices (U_prime, V_prime, and Y_prime)
  # given R_prime.
  # Each of the *_prime matrices should be 2x their originals,
  # because R_prime is 2x relative to R.
  # Rows with Last.stage == "services" are NA.
  new_R_ps()
doubleR$U_prime[[1]]
#>                Crude dist. Diesel dist. Elect. grid Gas wells & proc. NG dist.
#> Crude                    0            0           0                 0        0
#> Crude - Dist.         1000            0           0                 0        0
